text: hi everyone bad then he have tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new steve
lacey album gemini rights songwriter
multi-instrumentalist and producer mr
steve lacey he is back with his
sophomore full-length lp he is also
known for his work with tyler the
creator uh the internet blood orange
vampire weekend as well as caliyuchis to
name a few steve has also been building
up his solo career for years now at this
point he had that breakout 2017 demo ep
that a lot of people enjoyed which
showed a lot of promise but whatever
potential was there in my opinion was
not fully capitalized on when it came
time to release his full-length debut
which i would have loved to have loved
this record but there was a lot of weak
production and half-baked songs on this
thing that just made it really difficult
to praise however on gemiini rights i
think steve sounds much more prepared
for the task at hand while still staying
connected to that diy and lo-fi
recording style that gave him his
trademark outsider appeal in the first
place now like with steve's previous
record this new one over here brings a
series of rough and colorful meditations
on weirdo soul and psychedelic bedroom
pop it's a pretty trim album as well
with just 10 tracks on it including an
interlude and an intro whole thing lasts
about 35 minutes so yeah not nearly as
long as steve's last lp but some of the
awkwardness that was in the performances
of that record i think have carried on
to this new one ever so slightly as
there are some tracks here that i think
are lacking in a certain level of detail
or finesse whether that be the song
helmet where the stiff synth bass lines
and cycling beats as well as the small
spurts of rhythm guitar don't come
together as tightly as i would have
liked them to there are elements of the
track that remind me quite a bit of mac
demarco but his trademark slickness and
instrumental cohesion isn't really there
which is sad because i do think there is
a decent tune at the core of this one i
feel mostly the same way about the song
amber as well there is good storytelling
on this track the endearing piano parts
also make this a song that is a very
warm i kind of want to fall into it live
in the bliss of this track but the song
instrumentally never reaches a point of
lushness that would make me truly fall
in love with it and plus steve's
falsetto range that he leans into on
this one leaves a bit to be desired too
then there's sunshine which vocally
features fouche whose vocals i think are
a bit too
buried on this cut especially
considering how gentle her delivery is
and i kind of feel like these are vocals
you really want to get a clear view of
especially since we are hearing a story
on this track of a love of a romance
that
has gone awry at one point but seems to
be coming together in the end and yeah
in the lyrics there are some notes of
how toxic the dynamic between these two
may have been at one time and i do enjoy
those details but when it comes to the
singing and how these two bounce off of
each other emotionally there's little to
no chemistry there especially when it
comes to buying into the finishing
refrains of i still love you at the very
end like are you sure and as long as i'm
complaining i think for a record this
short sinking four whole minutes into a
spacy directionless meditation like cody
freestyle i mean the track is fine while
it's on and i do like its spacey and
cavernous synth layers which kind of
remind me of a dean blunt track or two
but steve's ranted and sung lines sort
of lose me after a while maybe somewhere
around the uh the deep throat bar but
with that being said there are actually
quite a few tracks on this record i was
impressed by for example the left field
latin feel of mercury is incredible the
hand percussion the acoustic guitar the
bittersweet vocal harmonies all come
together in a way that is uh somewhat
low-fi and rough around the edges but
cinematic at the same time and this
track is certainly proof that steve can
do a lot with a little or at least some
very muddy and sometimes like dirty
elements sonically this track also
contains one of the most passionate lead
vocal performances from steve on the lp
and the track generally just gets better
as it moves along as steve layers in
bits of horn and keys there's also the
lovely buttons on this record which i
think contains a fantastic chord
progression which makes not only for a
very grand entrance on the intro but i'm
completely enchanted by the spotlit
verses on the track as well and the way
the track generally just kind of builds
up intensely in a romantic sense there's
a strange sensual and quirky quality to
the track that is is just so prince in
the best way possible plus the sentiment
coming out of these lyrics you ran away
to save yourself from all the rain and
then i picked you up and then i showed
you love
and then we talked and let our guards
down which i think
is real as [ __ ] there's also the cute
and jangly bad habit that i enjoy quite
a bit the introverse on the track is so
boyish and silly and lovey-dovey i wanna
pinch its cheeks but like most of the
love stories on this record it's uh uh
not all gravy there's something a bit
amiss about this one as it seems like
steve is singing about a love that is a
bit of a lost opportunity or something
and he's hoping to come back around on
it and uh say hey if you're still
interested hop on the steve train the
song also undergoes a really cool
acoustic break on the back end with a
lot of lo-fi beats just more shows of
steve's instrumental creativity now as
far as the final light goes the only
track that really won me over was the
closer give you the world which is a
smooth and soulful cut with some decent
refrains strong chord progression a lot
of stevie wonder influence as well i'd
say yes it's a little low-fi like
everything else here but it doesn't take
away from the song's overall beauty
especially when it comes to the melodies
and lyrics but as romantic as some
elements of this track are the song
really does function as a goodbye not
just for this record but for this
relationship this romance that i imagine
much of this record is based around as
there's a lot of breakup and makeup
themes on this lp which as i listen to
this lp i still feel like i am making
heads or tales of because you know it's
it's it's a bit chaotic the record is a
bit chaotic in terms of like what it
really wants but maybe that's the gemini
energy radiating off of it
i'm not really sure but what is for
certain is that the first half of the lp
i think is a lot stronger than the
second but still overall i think that
this project is a sizable improvement
off of steve's last absolutely without a
doubt that is the case uh just stronger
songwriting stronger instrumental
layering better lyricism and song
structures sure are there elements of
steve's mixing and production and
performance that i think could use some
smoothing out yes but there's still
quite a few very good tracks here and i
think steve continues to
come into his own on this project and i
look forward to hearing the next one
from him especially considering the
improvement that we've heard between his
debut and sophomore i'm feeling a strong
six to a light seven on this one
transition have you given this record a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
is another video that you can check out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel anthony fantano steve lacey
forever
